title: What Factors Influence Your Fluid Needs?

sections.content: We often hear the advice: “Drink eight glasses of water a day!” — but in reality, it’s not that simple. Scientists have long abandoned this universal rule in favor of a more flexible approach: everyone’s fluid needs are unique and depend on many factors.

sections.subtitle: Body size and individual traits
sections.content: Men usually drink more than women, simply because on average their bodies are larger and require more water. Age also plays a role: both children and older adults may not feel thirst as clearly, so it’s harder for them to “catch” the right moment to drink.

sections.subtitle: Physical activity
sections.content: If you run, go to the gym, or simply move a lot throughout the day, your fluid requirements are higher. During activity, we lose water through sweat, and it needs to be replenished. Otherwise, fatigue, dizziness, and even dehydration can occur.

sections.subtitle: Climate and temperature
sections.content: Hot weather accelerates sweating, and the body loses fluids faster. But in winter, needs can also increase: dry indoor air and temperature changes cause additional fluid loss as well.

sections.subtitle: Special conditions
sections.content: Pregnant and breastfeeding women require more water to support both themselves and their baby. Illness also makes a difference — especially with fever, vomiting, or diarrhea — the body loses fluids much faster, and replenishing them becomes crucial.

sections.subtitle: Diet
sections.content: Spicy and salty foods increase thirst: salt retains water in the body but at the same time stimulates the desire to drink more. The type of diet also matters — for example, a high-protein diet increases fluid requirements.

sections.subtitle: Not just water
sections.content: Around 20% of daily fluid intake comes from food — especially vegetables, fruits, and soups. Drinks count too: tea, coffee, milk. Modern research confirms that moderate caffeine intake does not dehydrate the body, so your morning cup of coffee definitely “counts.”

sections.subtitle: How to know if you’re drinking enough?
sections.content: The main guide is how you feel. If you rarely feel thirsty, have good energy, your skin isn’t overly dry, and your head doesn’t feel heavy — you’re probably drinking enough. But if you notice fatigue, dry mouth, or trouble focusing, it’s a sign to pour yourself a glass of water.
